reviewText: The film that many dubbed Rock'em Sock'em Robots: The Movie initially surprised quite a few folks by being much better than a movie with that premise had any right to be. Set in 2020, when giant robots have overtaken the boxing circuit, Real Steel stars Hugh Jackman as Charlien Kenton, a former boxer-turned-robot trainer who is saddled with caring for his estranged young son Max when Max's mother dies. When the pair discover an obsolete sparring bot called Atom in a junkyard, they decide to rebuild him together, and an unlikely bond develops. I concede that the premise is silly, the dialogue a little cheesy, the plot -- like its mechanical protagonist -- a bit recycled, but if you're looking for a relatively straightforward underdog story with a smattering of father-son bonding, you could certainly do worse.

reviewText: What a great movie. Sure, the storyline is predictable, but the entertainment value is huge. The thing about this movie is that I could see the depicted robot fights, the computer technology, basically everything about it, as coming about in the normal course of our society. A wholly believable story, probably one of the easiest SF movies to watch in terms of suspending disbelief in quite some time -- and it's worth mentioning that this actually *is* science fiction in the classic sense; a little technology, all of it reasonable, around which wraps a good story. It's not a fantasy, as are many so-called SF stories today.So here we have really great robots, some awesome robot fighting, a not-overly annoying kid, and scenes that are (obviously intentionally) reminiscent of big-arena sports today, all combined with some feel-good stuff in the classic sense.It kind of looks like a kid's movie before you watch it; then when you watch it, there are adult-ish elements; at the end, I wondered who they thought they were marketing to? Perhaps that's why this didn't do all that well at the box office: the kid probably turned off the hard core SF types, the violence probably turned off legions of mommies and daddies, and the people who did go and enjoy it didn't make the case to others that it really wasn't a kid's movie or a movie that is all that violent in the living-things-getting-hurt sense of the word.Well, whatever the case there may be, I say, forget anything anyone says and just sit down with the desire to be entertained. I think you'll find that entertainment is delivered as desired, and in spades.They clearly set it up (very well) for a sequel, but it's unlikely we'll see one, again because of the box office performance. Too bad. I really, really liked it. I think you probably will too.

reviewText: I'm going to take the unusual step of stating the worst thing about this film at the very beginning. It is exactly the same as every other boxing/sport movie out there. The only thing different is the gimmick of having a robot as the fighter and the main character as the trainer. Having said that, on to the good things. As far as gimmicks go this one isn't bad. The concept may sound silly but what it allows for is giving the kid a major role in the film. This film is really about a father/son relationship. A VERY strained one too. Hugh Jackman hasn't seen his kid in years (since birth in fact) and when he gets custody of him after the mother's death his first act is to sell him to the kid's aunt for enough money to buy a new robot to train. Now in a film like this there would usually be very little for the kid to do. He would fill essentially the same role as the romantic interest, just being there to show the main character's human side. In this film the kid has a major role. He's the one who finds the robot and he's the one whose drive carries the plot forward. The robot boxing is almost secondary to the growing father/son bond.As might be obvious from the section above, the entire film rests on how well the father/son relationship works. With Hugh Jackman being a known factor it all rests on the choice of kid. Fortunately they chose well. I'm always a little finicky about child actors. They tend to either underplay or overplay their parts. Fortunately, the only overacting here comes in the context of the matches themselves where the characters are supposed to be performing and not simply reacting. The kid is a real find and manages to pull off strong willed without coming off as just stubborn. Hugh Jackman is excellent as usual as the impulsive and absentee father. His character is really a prick in the beginning having no obvious redeeming factors. As with all stories of this sort he's had a change of heart by the end, but the change comes gradually and doesn't feel forced. It helps that his son is an awful lot like him, which makes it easy to see why the two would bond.Other reviews have said that this is the movie thatTransformersshould have been, and there's a lot of truth to that. The man/machine interactions capture a fair amount of wonder and they never seem fake. Each bot has a unique appearance making it easy to tell them apart, unlike the previously mentioned film. The robots look real, and there were never any moments where you doubted that the characters were interacting with them. I feel that this was due to the use of a large number of practical effects instead of relying solely on cgi. What I really respected about this film was the way that it managed to capture all of the standard moments of this genre without hitting all of the cliches. There were many moments that I was waiting for with great non-anticipation but which never showed up. While the outcome of the film is never really in doubt the way in which the film gets there is very well handled. That said one or two of the characters were pretty stereotypical. The vile redneck Southerner is just an overused cliche by this point and the rich, evil foreigners vs. the small, underdog Americans has been done to death in so many movies.So in conclusion: This film adds nothing new to the sporting genre. It is basically the same story done a thousand times before. But while it may not be original it makes up for it by having a lot of heart and telling the same old story with a great deal of skill. The acting is excellent as are the effects. And the robot fights are quite thrilling. Coming to this movie with an open mind I was impressed at how well it all fit together in one entertaining package. Despite operating on what seems like a cheap gimmick it managed to mine that idea for all the dramatic potential it had. And the result is impressive.

reviewText: As much as I hate to say it, I actually liked this movie.  The movie does express some creativity, but maybe it's because it has so much nostalgia-factor for someone my age.  Nostalgia!?  Yeah, let me explain.  When I was a kid one of the hottest toys to come out was "Rock 'em Sock 'em Robots."  We never had one at our house, but a few lucky kids in the neighborhood had one and it was a real treat when you had a chance to play.  The popularity of that game has inspired its re-release [[ASIN:B00005BY8V Rock 'Em Sock 'Em ROBOTS Game].  Anyway, in this classic game two players face each other across a tiny ring, but they don't fight each other directly.  Each player has a set of controls which they use to try to "knock the block" off of their opponent.  The same thing happens in this movie, except the action is amped up about a billion times.Hugh Jackman is cast nicely as a down and out, has-been fighter from the days when people actually boxed each other.  Then came the robots and he couldn't quite make that transition.  In the process he lost his career, his wife, and pretty much everything.  He does have his son though.  And his son is simultaneously fanatical about robot boxing and about fixing things.  The little guy finds an old sparring-bot and manages to fix it up and power it up.Jackman does just about everything he can to quash his son's desire to use this old beat up "bot" in the ring, but he won't be stopped.  From here on out we are looking at a story line that has been used over and over again where an unknown underdog comes out of nowhere to take on the world.The characters are entertaining, the premis of boxing bots is fun, and the special effects are amazing.All in all this is a fun ride.  Though I debated between a 3-star and a 4-star rating, I opted for 4 stars because I wouldn't mind seeing it again sometime (even though I expected going in that I'd like the film only well enough for a 1 or 2-star rating).

reviewText: This is a movie that I just can't help glowing about. It's so much fun and uplifting that it's nearly impossible not to get swept up in the excitement and charm of the film. At one point in the story, the audience actually started clapping and cheering loudly. Now if you can wow a crowd as tough to please as NYC moviegoers, that's a huge credit to your film. I left the theater with a smile, knowing that it was $13.50 and 2 hrs well spent.Real Steel is a classic underdog story. It's about an irresponsible absentee father and his estranged son whose lives are transformed through their love of robot boxing. No one expected him to win, and no one expected his robot to last, but like all underdog stories, they surprise you and defy the odds. It's got good looking leads, cool animatronics/CG robots, humor, a hot Russian adversary babe, and lots of exciting fight choreography (Sugar Ray Leonard provided boxing consultation). Set about 10 years in the future, the science fiction elements are woven perfectly into the setting, which is modern and familiar, like present day America. The look of the film in certain scenes is a throwback to simpler times like the 40's and 50's instead of the shiny futuristic stuff you'd see in hard science fiction films. There's a great sense of nostalgia and innocence to the visual feel of Real Steel. We get some great vistas of rural America and "classic" small town life -- the kind of imagery that you'd perhaps see in a Norman Rockwell painting.This is a great looking film that's entertaining and makes you feel good at the end. There's a lot of product placement for HP, Dr Pepper and Microsoft, but they are not overly obnoxious. You can catch an "XBOX 720" gag in the boxing venue. Catch it in theaters if you can. Looking forward to the Blu-ray release. Highly recommended.

reviewText: There is a formula that usually comes with fight movies and as cliché and predictable as it is, it apparently works. It has been proven over and over with the "Rocky" and "Karate Kid" movies. Quite honestly, it would be a waste of time to list them all. Yet, throughout time, people still love them, regardless of the fact the scripts are as predictable as Monday morning. "Real Steel" is no different. The only difference in "Real Steel" is that it is set in the near future where humans no longer stand in the ring getting hit, but giant rockem' sockem' robots with quite a bit more mobility are doing the dirty work.Hugh Jackman plays Charlie Kenton, a former boxer and presently a low-life swindler who is in deep to numerous debt collectors. In his desperation to scramble up money to keep going in the robot boxing business, he is willing to risk everything at a moments notice and has no desire to know or have custody of a son named Max (Dakota Goyo). He is so void of anything moral, he takes a $50,000 bribe in order to take his son for one summer and sign away his parental rights to the mother's Aunt. See where this is going? I did, too."Real Steel" is full of cliché and predictability from beginning to end. There is a mountain of things to criticize. There is very thin development of the relationship between father and son, yet that storyline holds the purse strings. The final battle is not just similar to "Rocky", it is nearly a mirror of the movie "Rocky", all the way up to the `Adrian!' moment. I believe I even heard a few notes of the same song that ended the movie "Rocky" at the end of "Real Steel". The bad guys in the film are so cliché and over the top, it nearly ruined it for me. They are the stereotypical bad guys from the fight movies; the 'Cobra Kai' from "Karate Kid", `Drago' from "Rocky 3", except even more over the top.All that being said, the fight movie formula works. The robot animation is spectacular and realistic. It is a spectacle movie and if you want to see something like that, then "Real Steel" will not disappoint. It is entertaining from beginning to end and will be a great movie for those who don't mind the fact that its script has been done many times before. If you're looking for something deep and thought provoking, or unpredictable, look elsewhere.
summary: Real Steel is really cheesy and a real big ripoff of ROCKY

reviewText: This is essentially a father-son bonding experience over a boxing robot. Hugh plays an absentee father and former boxer who makes a living controlling a robot against various adversaries. Dakota is soon thrust in his lap, finds an aptitude for the sport, and becomes Hugh's better half in the enterprise as they travel around boxing. Dakota eventually obtains his own robot, and the two field it against the top robot champion in a Rocky-esque showdown.It's a very slickly-produced movie. The special effects are flawless: we might as well inhabit a world with giant lumbering robots. The fight scenes are least as exciting as those in Warrior and better than anything in Transformers. The latter is particularly surprising; the robots here are the equivalent of RC cars, but through evocative design and the emotional investment of the human characters, they have more personality than the sentient Transformers.There is a romantic subplot that involves the daughter of Hugh's former trainer, but it's of no consequence. More interesting are the various unscrupulous characters that inhabit Hugh's underworld early in the  movie. The real standout, though, is Dakota. He's absolutely convincing as hurt, slighted son, and later in his bonding with Hugh and the robot. Tremendous range in general, and not just for a child actor. He constantly steals scenes from Hugh.I do have a few nits to pick. This version of Hugh is significantly dumber than Wolverine. His early misfortunes are self-inflicted from errors improbable for the experienced robot handler he portrays. It's hard to suspend disbelief when your hard-luck protagonist blows his last shot by half-assing fight preparation. There's also a lack of personal growth at odds with the upbeat ending. He doesn't care about the kid at the outset, but while he becomes less bitter as the movie progresses, he ends up less a father than an accomplice. A number of like plot threads are left open after the final match. This is all a bit unsatisfying, but leaves the franchise primed for a sequel that should appear in 2014.My second nit involves some rather heavy-handed string-pulling by the director. We've got shots of the cute kid with a single tear, longing gazes by the romantic interest, extended montages, some truly cheeseball announcer commentary, and an emotional score that announces itself when we're supposed to feel something. The pity of it is, the actors don't need all this assistance, and most of it just pulled me out of the story.  The pastiche of Hollywoodisms isn't so egregious as in something like Pearl Harbor, but they do take away from could otherwise have been a fairly powerful film.All that aside, it's a very original premise with lots of excitement and good acting. The plot arc was transparent almost from the get-go, but I still wanted to stick around to see how it played out. That's a pretty solid endorsement.And how is it for children? The CGI robot battles won't raise eyebrows, though the two lead humans do get beaten up in one short scene. Obscenities are rare. The F-bomb doesn't make an appearance. There's no onscreen sex or anything resembling it. Gambling is a constant presence. The emotional scenes are no more traumatic than those in the Land Before Time. I'd say that any kid 8 or above should be fine.

reviewText: I know I'm a guy and like typical "man movies," but I really liked this movie and thought it was one of the best of 2011.  The story was interesting from beginning to end, the acting was great, and the special effects were awesome.This movie has been branded a boxing movie and even "Rocky with robots," but I would argue that this is more of a story about a father and his estranged son that build their relationship.  They simply use robot boxing as their common interest to bond over.  The fighting scenes are obviously great, but thankfully, they're only the finishing touches to this movie.  The story and relationships provide for a great foundation and an all around well done picture.  This is what separates it from other "man movies" since the scenes without boxing still progress the story and keep your interest peeked.One aspect that made this movie more "believable" and down-to-earth is that instead of being 100's of years into the future and with over the top electronics, the movie is set in the year 2020 and the technology is just a little more advanced than today.  This saves you from being distracted by flying cars and computer chips in people's brains.  Compare this to "Transformers" where it takes Optimus Prime 5 minutes to transform and where a cell phone becomes a living organism.Hugh Jackman, of course, delivers a solid performance, but more importantly, Dakota Goyo (who plays the son) is GREAT.  Too often we've seen great movies tarnished by child actors who need a little more practice before they get cast in a blockbuster movie (Star Wars: Episode 1 comes to mind).  But Dakota does a great job of being the smart alecky boy who loves video games and robot boxing.The special features on the blu ray aren't too spectacular, but maybe I had high hopes since I like the movie so much.  There is an app for your laptop or iPad that syncs with the movie as a 2nd screen, which sounds a lot cooler than it turns out to be.  But I'm also thankful that the special features are more than just trailers and production stills.Bottom line, I feel that Real Steel didn't get the credit it deserved, and had it not been for a snowy night with a rental movie, I wouldn't have even seen it myself.  Even if you're not much for boxing, this movie is still worth watching.
summary: One of the best movies of the year

reviewText: Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman) was a not-very-successful pugilist until he was forced into retirement when human fighters are replaced by hulking robots. Apparently, men beating each other to a pulp wasn't enough carnage for fight fans, facilitating the transition into full-sized Rock'em Sock'em Robots, although I can imagine that doctors who pointed to boxing as a source of brain damage and early-onset Parkinson's Disease would likely be pleased by such a change.Charlie is forced to change with the sport he loves, training bots to battle in underground battles held at rodeos, factories, and condemned zoos. Charlie longs for a shot in the World Robot Boxing league, but his arrogance has left him with a string of destroyed bots and owing thousands of dollars that he can't pay back.Forced to attend a custody hearing for his estranged 11 year old son Max (newcomer Dakota Goyo), Charlie talks Max's wealthy uncle into paying him to take care of Max for the summer. A huge robot fight fan, Max quickly takes an interest in his father's profession, much to Charlie's chagrin. When Charlie and Max break into a junkyard in search of replacement parts for a broken bot, Max discovers Atom, a discarded sparring bot that was built to endure a lot of punishment but not dish much out. Max insists on using Atom to get into the robot boxing world, and Charlie grudgingly agrees to train Atom to fight like a human boxer. The once-contentious father and son bond as Charlie's boxing savvy and Max's unwavering faith in Atom (as well as Max's amusing dance moves) lead to Atom's rise through the underground ranks, catching the eye of the WRB. And after Atom impressively defeats a WRB contender, Max publicly issues a challenge to Zeus, the reigning undefeated champ, leading to a "David vs. Goliath" showdown for all the metal marbles (or would that be ball bearings?).Also populating this film are Lost's Evangeline Lilly, essentially filling out the "Adrian role" as Bailey Tallet, the daughter of Charlie's deceased trainer who has turned her father's old boxing gym into a pseudo-Frankenstein's workshop for Charlie's bots. Anthony Mackie from The Hurt Locker appears as Finn, an underground promoter and one of Charlie's few "friends," and Kevin Durand as Ricky, one of Charlie's former in-ring adversaries who Charlie owes money to after skipping out on a bot-fighting bet.Real Steel prescribes to all the cliches started by the Rocky films of a down-on-his luck underdog who defies the odds and gets a shot at the big time, but the film also has a little bit in common with another Sylvester Stallone film, Over The Top. Both films involve a father and his estranged son who grate on each other at first, but end up working out their abandonment issues and bond over a similar interest even as outside forces and their own clashing personalities threaten to rip them apart. Many would also find shades of the Transformers films in the "battling robots" plot, but unlike those films whose attraction lied mainly in mechanical carnage of CGI-bot-on-CGI-bot violence, Real Steel's strength lies in its human players, namely Charlie and Max, giving the film a soul. And you can't help but cheer when Charlie starts shadow boxing at ringside during the Zeus fight.
summary: Formulaic, but an enjoyable crowd pleaser film

reviewText: **Originally posted on "#1 Hits From Another Planet" - 10/11/11**Real Steel is the kind of movie you can predict at nearly every turn, yet it really doesn't matter. Though it's not quite my favorite film of the year, it made me feel more ecstatic at its end than any other movie of 2011. To borrow a cliché, it's the "feel good movie of the year." I feel so dirty typing those lame words, but it's true.Yes, if you've seen a boxing movie or a family drama, you've pretty much experienced this story already, but it's such a powerful, archetypal tale. And Real Steel tells it perfectly. Every good boxing movie needs some secret weapons. This one's got two. First, the robots. Dear god, the robots. They are so frickin' cool. Each one featured has its own look and personality to match, but it's Atom, the "protagonist" robot, that really gets under your skin. In a lot of ways, this is a "boy and his robot story," and Atom's got just enough humanity to make him feel real. The special effects are jaw-dropping, so jaw-dropping that you'll forget you're watching something from a computer. Best of all, they're present to serve the story... not the other way around.But as kickass as the robots are, the movie's real strength lies in its leads. Hugh Jackman's played variations on his Real Steel character before and, perhaps because of that, has it down pat. He's clearly enjoying himself, which translates to the screen. The arc his character goes through is expected, but so satisfying. There's a bit at the end that totally got me. Just the look on his face. You'll know what I mean when you see it. Then there's young Dakota Goyo. Where do I begin? I've gotta be honest and say that the trailers for this movie made him out to be the typical, annoying Hollywood kid. It's a disservice, because his performance in this movie is nothing short of astonishing. He's got more charisma than any kid actor I've seen in a long time and really, really commits to his scenes. Most of the tears I shed (and there were quite a few... I'm an ultra sappy moviegoer if the movie is right) were doen to him. I just can't believe that such a young kid can take over a film like this. It really was his from the moment he was onscreen.So there you go. See it. It's the kind of the movie that's so much better than you'd expect given the premise. Don't expect a reinvention of the wheel, but go in to see those established wheels spinning quite productively and passionately. It's a crowd pleaser, for sure.
summary: Much Better than I had Expected!!

reviewText: Movies like this really tick me off. Great idea that, with a few minor changes, could have been incredible.Here's the scoop. Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman) is a screw-up. He fathered a son he hasn't seen in years. He has a robot he drives around the country picking up gigs for chump change. His son's mother dies and he's happy to let boy's aunt take custody of him....for a price. Through a fluke he ends up with the boy for a few weeks. They come across an old robot which they fix up and take on tour where they proceed to climb the bot-fight ladder to the ultimate match.This is a nifty flick, but it could have been so much more with only a few minor changes. First off the is the script. I don't know that I'd change anything there. I liked it just fine. What I would change is Hugh Jackman. I just don't think he's that good. I did see him recently in "The Prisoners" and he was really good, but generally he has nowhere near the gravity to pull this off. I'd put in someone like Russ Crowe, Michael Fassbender or maybe Ryan Gosling. I'd also put in a different director. If you look at Shawn Levy's history, he's done all cutesy, light weight stuff. Put in Pete Travis or Alfonso Cuaron and this could have been a true powerhouse of a film. Now, being based on a kids toy from the early 60's, maybe light and cute is what the producers were going for, but I saw so much potential in making this, not just an entertaining flick, but a truly great film.Now, with over 500 reviews already logged for this movie, I'd be really surprised if anyone even reads this. But I just saw it for the third time and it frustrated me as much as it entertained me so i had to speak my piece.

reviewText: On Monday September 28, 2011, I and my son were invited to an advance screening of the new DreamWorks Pictures' movie Real Steel that was shown at the Uptown Palladium in Birmingham. MI. It turned to be one exciting film that we both enjoyed from beginning to end.Real Steel takes place in the year 2020 where boxing is now done  by robots that fight to the death.  Hugh Jackman plays Charlie Kenton, a washed up former fighter turned robot boxing promoter that has been down on his luck for a good while.  Charlie has been trying to hit it big in robot boxing, but ends up owing large sums of money to some very dangerous people.One day he finds out that his former girlfriend has died, leaving him as the official guardian to his 11 year old son Max (played by Dakoto Goyo), who Charlie has not seen since since Max was a baby.  Max's aunt (played by Hope Davis) wants Charlie to give up custody of Max to her and her very rich husband.  And Charlie sees this situation as a way to get quick cash to buy another fighting robot so that he can get out of debt.But what Charlie does not count on is the fact that his son Max is one tough kid that shows him how to have the heart to try to win again against the odds.  And Max teaches Charlie that when you do what you love, the money will come.Real Steel is an exciting and endearing film.  Even though we all knew how the story would end, we could not help cheering for Charlie as he discovers how to finally be a dad and how to finally be a winner. And Dakoto Goyo who played Max is one awesome kid actor who made everyone in the audience fall in love with him.  My son likes his movies exciting and the fight scenes in Real Steel are in your face loud and graphic.  It was like watching a giant robot boxing video game on the movie screen.The most exciting part of the movie for me were the scenes that were filmed right here in Detroit.  Yep, this movie contains footage and aerial shots of downtown Detroit, including Cobo Hall and the GM Renaissance Center.  I was bursting with Detroit pride when I saw my city on the big screen.Just a warning to parents that this film is rated PG-13 because of the graphic boxing violence and because it contains quite a bit of adult language.If you like a real good underdog story that is funny, captivating and heartfelt, Real Steel delivers on all counts and will open in theaters nationwide of Friday, October 7th, 2011.

reviewText: REAL STEEL is a clever movie in that it takes a video game concept (though the idea is from a short story by Richard Matheson interpreted by Jeremy Leven, Dan Gilroy and written for the screen by John Gatins), keeps intact the videogame lovers' approach to fantasy and action, and introduces some adult versions of acting out  that make for a solid message.At first the movie seems trite - a grown man, ex-boxer Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman, buff, surly and in fine acting condition) buys and sells and enters robots who perform in a circus style boxing arena where years earlier real men boxed. We soon discover that this is future-set story where robot boxing is a popular sport and centered on a struggling promoter (Jackman) who thinks he's found a champion in a discarded robot. During his hopeful rise to the top, he also discovers he has an 11-year-old son Max (Dakota Goyo), in the midst of a custody battle with Charlie's deceased wife's sister and husband (Hope Davis and James Rebhorn).  Charlie, ever on the outlook to pay off his debts and find financing for buying new robots to train for boxing matches,  makes a deal with the couple, and agrees to care for Max for a summer while the couple visit Europe.  Max wants to know his father but on his terms.  The two males are aided by the owner of Charlie's training gym - Bailey (Evangeline Lilly) - and it is her intervention that helps the two males join forces and become involved with a discarded robot, Atom, they make a champion by working together.The tenderness of the film takes a while to settle in, but in the end it is not easy to deny that the story of a reluctant father and a self sufficient son finding that arm platform of relationship, able to endure disappointments as well as triumphs.  Jackman and Goyo are a terrific team and the other cast members, especially  Lilly and Anthony Mackie, are solid. Shawn Levy's direction deserves credit for pulling the whole thing together. This is not just another silly CGI flick: there is a core a beauty to the film that makes it not only entertaining but heartwarming, too.  Grady Harp, January 12

reviewText: "We all wanted to make the kind of movie that we loved when we were young, the kind fo get-out-of-your-seat, cheer-for-the-underdog kind of movie that was going to be visually cool, but would be tonally different than you expect a robot movie to be -- a tone that may be closer to WALL-E or Iron Giant than it is to Transformers or Terminator."Real Steel director Shawn Levy says this on the audio commentary (THANK YOU!) on both the Blu-ray and DVD of the movie, which had a big opening weekend in theaters and also on home video sales and rentals.Indeed, Real Steel is very much like Iron Giant in spirit, and also like a very high tech Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots. It's also an update of films like The Champ, in which a child helps a former achiever to reach again for the top, as a success and as a person.As Levy also remarks in the commentary, the choice of likable star Hugh Jackman for a role that is unlikable for a good portion of the film is a major reason for how well it succeeds. Perhaps by design, Jackman never really comes across as a believable jerk, though he is very earnest and real in the role (despite his occasional tangles between his Australian accent with a "street tough" American dialect). He's ably supported by Dakota Goyo as his estranged young son (a performance that could make or break the film, but it this case "makes" it) and Evangeline Lilly, whose relatively small role radiates immense charm and appeal.The robots and the spectacular effects are stars, of course, in this type of film, but Levy is careful to keep the real and the steel in balance. Visually, the filmmakers achieved what he calls a "retro modern" look in that takes place a few fictitious years from now. In order to make the robots more relatable to the actors, a combination of CG and full-size robots were created.Levy also makes great use of the Michigan locations -- very stark and Blade Runner-ish without augmentation, thanks to the highly industrial look of gigantic assembly plants and scrapyards. In an early fight sequence, hundreds of extras are seen throughout a sprawling structure that was not a special comp effect, but a real place where large automobile parts where shipped in by train.Real Steel isn't designed to be confused with The Artist. reviewText: I think I'm about to use up my quota of exclamation points. Boxing robots! Wait, let me write that in caps... BOXING ROBOTS!! I am currently eating crow about REAL STEEL. I saw the trailer for it weeks ago and pronounced it a stupid rock 'em sock 'em robot punching flick. Turns out, it IS a rock 'em sock 'em robot punching flick, but it is awesome. Enough human elements are introduced to ground the wackadoo premise. Atom, the underdog boxing robot, works on your bump of sympathy, sneaks past your defenses, clocks you with its unexpected soulfulness. Yes, I am anthropomorphising an inanimate object, but that is one damn evocative boxing robot.In the near future, the Sweet Science has replaced its human pugilists with metal robots, robots being more durable and destructive and therefore more likely to sate our cravings for carnage and claret. But it's odd watching Hugh Jackman play a shifty, irresponsible ex-boxer and nogoodnik - name of Charlie Kenton - who ekes out a living by traveling from place to place and pitting his ramshackle boxing robot in seedy matches. Charlie Kenton's line of debt continues to mount because an impulsive character like Charlie can't be bothered to think things thru and he usually ends up with his nads in a sling. Fleeing another incurred debt, Charlie learns of an old girlfriend's passing and, even more relevant, that this leaves him possibly stuck with their eleven-year-old kid Max. It's a measure of Hugh Jackman's appeal that you still find him likable even though his role calls for his being a shirker, a welcher, and an absentee father. The film, naturally, gives him opportunities for redemption, and Jackman makes it work. But, don't get it twisted, no one sells the heel-to-hero journey quite as grandly as Tom Cruise.Because of this and that, Charlie Kenton ends up taking his estranged, suspicious son on the road, and Max turns out to be an avid robot boxing fan. Crummy luck or sheer inept boxing strategizing has caused Charlie's robots to succumb to getting their metal mugs caved in. One night, during an illegal run thru a metal scrap yard (in search of enough parts to construct another fight 'bot), Charlie and Max stumble upon a buried robot, an old and smaller model named Atom. Max promptly adopts it like it's a pet. It's apropos; thematically, REAL STEEL exudes a huge whiff of "a boy and his dog."Atom is a relic, an old Generation II model, a lowly sparring 'bot. It's able to absorb massive doses of punishment but isn't much in the way of an offensive arsenal. What it does have is a rare "shadow" function which allows it to mimic Charlie's boxing moves... and Max's dancing. Yes, boxing DANCING robots!! Take that, Bumblebee!This kid, Dakota Goyo, who plays Max, bursts out of nowhere and makes an impact with his good acting and savvy and moxie. Max is a spirited kid who won't back down, and I found myself admiring him as the grown-up in this father-and-son pair. And I dare you not to think it adorable when you watch Max and his robot bust out their dance routine during their ring walk. If you've seen your share of sports movies then the story thread hits familiar beats. But it's easy to yield to the underdog theme. Atom is clearly smaller and not as sleek and less powerful than the monster robots he faces in the ring. The fights are rousing. Metal smashing metal, servos and gears and widgets and other metallic whatnot sent hurtling willy-nilly. Maybe it helped that Sugar Ray Leonard was consulted for the fight choreography. Atom certainly exhibited some slick moves. I know the theater audience was frequently vocal and involved and cheering. We track Atom's rise in the pugilistic ranks as he gains street creds and word of mouth pub. It's not long before he cracks the World Robot Boxing scene and set to take on the mighty Zeus, the greatest robot boxer of all time.Throw in an Evangeline Lilly who makes the most of her limited role as the romantic interest, and what we have is a movie that doesn't lack for warmth and heart and surprising emotional content. REAL STEEL caters towards them kids, but there's also enough here for grown-ups to savor. The robots, whether animated thru CG or animatronics, are flawlessly rendered. I hear there's already a sequel in the works. Good. Maybe then they'll address the topic of Atom's sentience which was sort of hinted at but then promptly dropped. Bro, go check this out.
summary: "In his first professional fight, hailing from parts unknown... Atom!"

reviewText: When I first saw commercials of this and saw it was compared to Rocky, I did not care for it. I have no interest in the Rocky franchise. Still, what harm was there in renting it? My opinion now hurts.Charlie Kenton is a "has-been," no longer able to catch up to his past debts. But that's not the only reason he no longer holds robot fights. That, along with a custody battle for his young, estranged son, sets off a small series of events that help bring him back up to the world of robot fights. Especially with how the robot he's using, "Atom," is a first-generation fighter with a couple features that help the fight progression keep level.At first, like in the show Spartacus, Charlie has to go through underground, dirty-style fighting rings. Beyond that, he's also getting to know his son, who has a very good, working knowledge on the history of robot fighting.On the angles: even though Evangeline Lily's character, Bailey Tallet, is considered, from the amazon.com review, to be the perfunctory love interest, I did not catch a strong "love interest" angle through the movie. Maybe hints of attraction, but nothing that forces the film away from the action, nor the drama that drives the scenes. Then there's the "underdog" subtheme, showing how a little kid, with a huge heart, can have people's attention and seriously peeve off the big-corporate people (how he stands up to the Japanese boss and his assistance with his outright gall actually had me cheering, something I normally don't do for a movie). It didn't feel off-setting for this movie. Instead, it felt contextually appropriate for that to be here. It also felt appropriate for the kid, young and highly rambunctious and extremely energetic, to have the most energy in his acting for this film. Jackman's character is also rambunctious, but appropriately less-than for an adult. Lily' character is more of a grounding character so the guys don't get too wild and set everyone in a good background check, of sorts.Durand does a decent presentation of a man seeking his money from the man who owes him a debt (even if he has to be a typical southern-style loan shark), and Yune's character is both serious and seriously comical (particularly with how his machine's defeated and how he reacts to it, it made me crack up pretty good).So, all-in-all, this was a surprisingly good film to watch, with a breakout performance by a new actor, memorable performances by veteran actors and actresses, great special effects, a nice storyline to keep things going, and truly excellent fight scenes with each robot (and humans), along with good dashes of subtle humor to keep it grounded and not so bland with testosterone.Now for the hard part: waiting for the sequel to come out.

reviewText: There is no doubt this movie is relatively entertaining on purely robot fights, but there are plenty of reasons why it's not a 5-star movie.Based in the "near" future, Real Steel stars Hugh Jackman as Charlie Kenton, a former fighter who uses the majority of his resources in life fueling his problems as a degenerate gambler with ADHD (either that, or he cares not to watch his fights or read instruction manuals).  Charlie nickels and dimes his way through life, shunning responsibility in favor of the next robot fight he'll bet upon and inevitably lose.  Along comes his estranged son Max (Dakota Goyo) and a heaping dose of Deus ex machine to save the day.  In no time at all they steal a decommissioned sparring robot that, through the gee-whiz engineering prowess of a wunderkind 11 year old, is suddenly knocking on the door of the championships with only a few fights on record.  Will they win?  Will Charlie and his son reconcile?  Anyone who has seenOver the Topshould know the answers already, and, like me, should start calling the movie Reel Steal.Underdog vs. champion movies work really well.  Mixed with sports they work even better.  But if we learned anything from The Blind Side, irritating children who command far too much screen time do not work all that well.  The script is cliché-ridden, and Goyo is irritating beyond belief  Seriously, he's "Hmong actors inGran Torino"-horrible.  Nearly ruined, Real Steel's FX rises above Goyo's hip-hop Anakin portrayal and provides a bunch of seamless, metal crunching battle scenes.  Had this movie just stuck to the futuristicRock 'Em Sock 'Em ROBOTSroutine, it would have worked much better.  As it stands, however, sentimentality was thrown in, with a kid and father who never actually acknowledge one another other than business partners, and a third wheel (Evangeline Lilly) who was so cursory she probably got paid in game room tokens.Kids will enjoy the entire movie.  Discerning viewers will nit-pick the very corny melodrama, lack of character development, and mixed messages (seriously, the dude actively commits grand larceny with his kid).  All viewers should enjoy the robot fights.  Winner by split decision.
summary: Slightly rusty, but a winner by split-decision

reviewText: In the not-too-distant future (2027) Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman; X-Men, The Prestige) plays a down on his luck, scheming ex-boxer who signed away the rights to his son at birth, owes every unsavory soul he could find some money, is behind on his rent, and even more behind on his dignity.  He's down on himself so much that he won't even tolerate hearing accolades of his past triumphs.  Charlie pushes everyone away so far and hard that he can't even remember how old his own son is (who is 11).The ultimate scumbag, Charlie sells custody of his son (Max, played by Dakota Goya; Thor).  But to collect, he must spend the summer with him.  He uses the $50K custodial bounty to buy an ex-pro robot boxer to pit in a dirty underground fight. Guess how that turns out for this winner?Charlie teaches Max about haste, greed, theft, and the history of sport-fighting that led to the robot boxing sensation.  Max, a fan of robot boxing, teaches him how to dream with his devout support of an obsolete model junkyard robot.  Because Max won't let up, Charlie has no choice but to submit and teach him about the sport.  "You've played video games, right?  Well this is just like that.  Except that this one's a 1000 pound robot."  Atom, as Max names him, is a sparring bot that mirrors fighting styles.  Atom is under-sized, fast and designed to take hits, not deliver them.  Charlie has doubts.  Max has dreams.  And Atom is special.Charlie teaches Max what the audience wants and trains the bot to box.  Max works up a mean robot shadow-dancing routine to give Atom a persona.  Atom serves as a friend to the boy and an inspiration to both of them.  This makes Charlie smile for reasons beyond money.  When he sees Max win with Atom, it's as if Charlie begins to think he can, too.  They quickly beat some big names and make one for themselves and go pro aiming for Zeus, the pro-champ and an evolving, fully autonomous robot.  How do you beat that?For the boxing enthusiasts out there, Sugar Ray Leonard sets up an original rope-a-dope for our junkyard scrapper in honor of Muhammad Ali.  In Real Steel, Atom may lack the palpable emotional output of Wall-E, but this faceless robot manages to make us "feel".  And it may not quite be Rocky, but when Atom wins, I feel like "I win."  This father-son team and junkyard robot turned hero really made my day!  The hits are hard, the drive is contagious, and the victory is emotional!

reviewText: When I first saw previews for this movie, my first thought was "Hey, they finally made a movie out of the Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots game."  Silly, I know, but in this day and age where they can make a successful film franchise out of a toy line (the "Transformers" films) and a Disneyland ride (the "Pirates of the Caribbean" films), then why not a game?  It could work if they have the right people behind it, right?  (This was before the bomb that was "Battleship" came out, mind you...)Unlike the aforementioned "Battleship" movie, however, "Real Steel" is a wonderful movie.  It's not a heavy science-fiction film, or really even an action film despite featuring fighting robots.  It's a film with heart behind its metallic brawn, and even though the robots get plenty of screen time it's the human element that makes this film shine.Based loosely on a Richard Matheson short story, "Real Steel" follows Charlie, a washed-up former boxing champ turned fighting-robot manager who's deeply in debt and has just lost his last fighting robot in a particularly brutal match.  He finds himself a reluctant caretaker to his estranged son, Max, and ends up taking the boy with him as he travels the country, trying to scrape together funds to buy or build a new robot and pay his debts.  When Max comes across an outdated sparring bot abandoned in a junkyard and decides to restore it and fight it, Charlie is skeptical... but Atom, Max's bot, turns out to be far tougher than anyone realizes, and soon Atom becomes a sensation in the underground fighting league.  And it may be Atom that ends up drawing father and son together.The plot of this movie is fairly predictable -- you've probably seen it in a hundred sports movies before and are likely to see it again.  But that doesn't mean the plot doesn't work here.  The premise of a near-future where robots do the fighting in the boxing ring adds a fresh twist to the plot, and the characters bring a lot of heart to their roles.  Hugh Jackman proves to be a versatile, phenomenal actor, and brings a gruff pathos to his role as Charlie.  Max starts off as the typical whiny child, but develops into a likable and spunky kid as the movie progresses.  The "villains" of this film (the creator and manager of the champion fighting bot Zeus, and a borderline-sadistic promoter to whom Charlie owes money) are fairly one-note and flat, but that just makes it all the more satisfying when they get their just dues.  And Atom, despite being mute and personality-less throughout the film, somehow manages to win the viewers heart as well -- who doesn't like an underdog story, and want to see the little guy win?The visual effects in this film are phenomenal as well.  The film is portrayed as a "near-future" where many elements are similar, but the robots don't come across as a jarring addition.  At times it's easy to forget one is watching CGI effects and not actual machinery, and each of the fighting bots has its own unique look.  It makes me wish this movie had come with a decent toy line, because I know I would buy myself a miniature version of Atom or Noisy Boy if I could.  Oddly enough, the most jarring "special effects failure" in the film comes from the fight in the opening scene, where a fighting robot takes on a bull -- it's quite easy to tell when they stop using an actual animal and start using a CGI dummy.  But then, visual effects haven't come far enough to produce animals that don't look fake, I suppose...This film has been described as "Rocky with robots," and I have to say it's an accurate description.  It has a LOT of heart, great acting, and a story that has been told many times but manages to not be stale or cheesy here.  Even if you're not a sci-fi fan, I'd give this movie a look -- it's a good heartwarming film, and the robots are just the cherry on top for me.Recommended for ages 10 and up, due to language and violence.
summary: Rocky meets Transformers -- a robot movie with a lot of heart

reviewText: Folks, "Real Steel" is the real deal!  This is a 5-star fantastic, funtastic, futuristic movie with a lovely human redemptive plot that gives it focus, meaning and purpose.  It is easy to imagine this becoming a mind-bending rock'em sock'em robot comupter-generated sci-fi geek movie.  But it's not; in fact, it is far from it!  What it is, is a love story that happens to involve fighting robots, and the love story is multi-level and done so well that you'd best have that proverbial box of tissues with you. I guarantee your eyes will water as this film lands a kcockout blow to your heart.Mix 1979's "The Champ" (relationship of Ricky Schroder and Jon Voight) with 1976's "Rocky" (relationship of Sylvester Stallone and Talia Shire) and throw in some Rock'em Sock'em robots, and you have a story that will sweep your tech imagination away, while at the same time delivering devastating uppercuts to your heart.I usually do not praise too many movies enthusiastically, but I can't praise this movie enough for scoring one KO after another in terms of acting, casting, script, screenplay, music, drama, and climactic ending.  It's all here, and it leaves you wanting more as the credits roll.The film centers around the evolving relationship between absentee, deadbeat, scam-artist father, Charlie (Hugh Jackman) and betrayed and emotionally distant son Max (Dakota Goyo). Charlie used to be top-ranked boxer and a man people respected, but he lost his self-respect, lost his marriage, lost his only son, and as the movie begins, he is one short step ahead of several loan sharks wanting their money. Charlie's a loser with a capital "L".  He is still in the fight game, but now boxing involves robots, and Charlie's robots are as junky as he is.  But then fate steps in in the form of his long-lost son, Max, and a new robot called Atom.  Suddenly, the equation of loss that is Charlie's life changes, and the question then becomes one of redemption, not only for Charlie himself, but also for Max and Charlie's girlfriend, Bailey (Evangeline Lilly).  Can Charlie  find the inspiration to fight to save himself, his son, and his future, or will he once again weasle away and and throw everyone under the bus in the process?  No spoilers here!  You have to see this for yourself, and in the process, you will remember this film for a long time to come.  Like me, you will be cheering in the final moments of the film, not only for Atom the robot, who is fighting against virtually insurmountable odds, but also for Charlie, who is fighting against pretty steep odds himself.This film is not deep.  It probably won't win any Academy awards, but it might just win your heart.Rated PG-13 (language).kone
summary: Real Steel Delivers a Knockout to the Heart
Title: Real Steel

reviewText: "Real Steel" is great! This is how the story goes: In the near-future, where the sport of boxing has gone hi-tech, Charlie Kenton is a washed-up fighter who lost his chance at a title when 2000-pound, 8-foot-tall steel robots took over the ring. Now nothing but a small-time promoter, Charlie earns just enough money piecing together low-end bots from scrap metal to get from one underground boxing venue to the next. When Charlie hits rock bottom, he reluctantly teams up with his estranged son Max to build and train a championship contender. As the stakes in the brutal, no-holds-barred arena are raised, Charlie and Max, against all odds, get one last shot at a comeback.The cast led by Hugh Jackman (as Charlie) is great. The directing by Shawn Levy (who also produced) is great. The story by Dan Gilroy & Jeremy Leven & the screenplay by John Gatins is great.The music by Danny Elfman is great. The cinematography by Mauro Fiore is great. The film editing by Dean Zimmerman is great. The casting by Richard Hicks & David Rubin is great. The production design by Tom Meyer is great. The art direction by Seth Reed, Jason Baldwin Stewart & Jeff Wisniewski is great. The set decoration by Victor J. Zolfo is great. The costume design by Marlene Stewart is great.This is a great boxing drama with great family values instilled in it. This is fun, entertaining and fast-paced. Hugh Jackman is great, as usual. This is another great film from Shawn Levy. This is "Rocky" meets "Transformers".

reviewText: 3.3 starsI normally love Jackman, but this is his worst movie, due mainly to truly weak direction by Shawn Levy. That and a hackneyed Disneyesque script make this potentially fine idea limp and boring. I know a lot of folks love this flick, and more power to them, but while watching it with a fellow lover of action films we kept grimacing at how predictable it all was.The robots are fun, no doubt, but Real Steel feels for the most part like an ABC Afterschool Special. So many cheesy and hamhanded moments and so few truly funny lines. Jackman does his best but clearly Levy isn't very good at drawing our truly fine performances, and the seen-it-all-before script does no one any favors.We were really psyched to see this after all the hype, but in the end were mostly bored by a film that looks pretty good but never really got us excited.

reviewText: From the cloying inspirational soundtrack to the Kinkaide-inspired amber sunsets; to the big eyed precocious kid who is so much more smarter than the adults around him, to the sentimental beautiful girlfriend who hopes her would-be boyfriend grows up. The only thing this movie was missing was a scruffy dog. And 'Atom The Robot' comes awfully close to that.I wasn't looking for some kind of hardened combat-to-the-death flick, but this static predictable sugarfest had me wistful for a dose of German avant-garde experimental film - and I detest German avant-garde experimental film.Would've been much more enjoyable had the filmmakers taken a slightly darker edge, placed the characters in a slightly more challenging plot. And importantly, hired a less adorable, less smarmy adult-sounding kid. Every time he uttered, "I got this", I wanted to puke.No point in really doing an in-depth review - how hard is it to figure this one out?As it stands, it's the robot reboot of the 1987 Sylvester Stallone flick "Over the Top". And that movie was terrible. And speaking of Sly - he ought to sue the producers for ripping hisboxing franchiseoff. Cinematographic plagiarism at its worst.Want robots and a really fun ride? Rewatch one of 'The Transformers'. I know I will.Movie Note: One plothole that had me confused - how does "underground" robot fighting work? I mean, the open public competition already has them destroying/killing one another. So what exactly would be the dark side of this sport? Getting sodomized by the winning robot?Actually, that would've made this movie more interesting. Talk about an incentive to win. <g>

reviewText: Take the story from Rocky, add giant robots, an annoying kid and some rock 'n roll and you'll experience Real Steel.Hugh Jackman used to be a boxer before the sport was outlawed. Now he operates a giant robot in the new boxing ring. Unfortunately, he's a lousy human being. He's fathered a kid but cares nothing for his offspring. His main concern is making money with the bots.When he's called to court for a custody hearing, Jackman makes a deal in order to "watch" his son for the summer for a large sum of money. (He's the cliched low-life.)During the summer, father and son find and update an old sparring robot in order for it to fight in the arenas. This bot was created to take a beating and in this way is very much the robotic version of the Italian Stallion.The film tries very hard to get you to believe this robot is alive, having it stare into a mirror and shadow box with the boy, but we're lucky in that they kept it lifeless. It's just a robot but people still cringe when the punches are delivered.Young boys will love the boxing robots and the high-octane music while their moms will enjoy seeing Hugh Jackman become a better man.Seriously, Jackman is the reason this movie is so good. He has the ability to take a less than so-so movie and turn it into a fairly successful flick.Outside of the incredibly annoying kid and a few bad examples of foul language, Real Steel is a decent movie.

reviewText: The filmmakers hit their target audience with this fight themed drama about a washed up boxer (Hugh Jackman) who is now heavily invested in robot fighting which is now all the rage in a near future America.  Unfortunately, Charlie (Jackman) must have taken too many hits to the head as he makes ridiculous bets with guys who insist on getting their money now when they win.  What a concept.  Charlie finds out that a former flame has died - his reaction, OK - and that he now has custody of a son aged somewhere between 8 and 11.  He's really not sure.  Max (Dakota Goyo) has an aunt who wants to adopt him.  Charlie agrees but not until he bribes the aunt's rich husband for $50K.  That's enough to get another fighting robot.Charlie agrees to take Max for the summer, and then turn him over to his aunt.  Max knows nothing about this of course.  Max becomes an asset because he knows his roboboxing.  They find a discarded sparring robot at a junk yard and clean him up.  What do ya' know.  He starts to win.  I'm about as bored writing this plot as the film often becomes.  Every match outcome is easily predicted.  We know that the reluctant father and the lonely boy will bond.  We know Charlie will reconcile with his current girlfriend (an underutilized Evangeline Lilly).  If you've ever seen "Rocky" or the new "Warrior" or the old animated "Iron Giant", then you've probably seen this one too.It really isn't all that bad however.  In fact, it delivers familiar moral prescriptions to a whole new audience not familiar with the previous films. The transfer looks very good, complete with a nice mixture of live filming mixed in with CGI tricks.  The sound is magnificient in the HD surround.

reviewText: First off, the trailers didn't quite sell the movie to me, so I went in the theater today with low expectations. I left pleasantly surprised...It's set in the near future where boxing and even mixed martial arts doesn't display enough carnage for audiences. They turn to 8 foot robots controlled by human "trainers" to get their fix. Hugh Jackman turns in one of his best non-Wolverine performances as a no good father and former boxer who now uses fighting robots to make (or in his case lose) money. He chooses to sell his son, left alone after his mother died, for $100,000 to the boy's Aunt and Uncle. But first he has to spend a couple of months with him while the boy's future guardians are in Europe. It turns out that his 11-year-old knows even more than he does about robotic fighting. They end up stumbling upon an older model bot (named Atom) in a junk yard and from there they begin to train it and almost in Rocky like fashion Atom becomes a crowd favorite and gets a shot at the title. I thought the boy actor was excellent as well. He had a lot of attitude, but he never got annoying. Evangeline Lilly of Lost fame is here to showcase her beautiful face, but doesn't get much more to do than be a love interest for Jackman's character.The CGI is great. Unlike most scenes in the Transformers movies, you can actually tell the robots apart and the action is easy to follow.Sure it has the usual corny moments and the giant robots fighting in a ring sometimes comes off silly, but I really enjoyed Real Steel. It sometimes feels like an emotional family film about the relationship between a boy and his father, but it doesn't get too sappy and there is plenty of action to balance out all of the feel good stuff. Overall, I was never bored and it was more fun than I expected it to be.3 and 1/2 out of 5 stars
summary: Optimus Prime ain't got nothing on Atom

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much, but was pleasantly surprised by this movie.  My son, who is about the same age as the boy in the film, really enjoyed it.Real Steel is about a washed up loser named Wolverine who decides to fight robots after getting kicked out of the X-Men.  Well... maybe that's not entirely accurate, but the dude is a washed up loser nonetheless.  The guy fights robots for a living, but hits a bit of a hurdle when a girl that he knocked up dies and he gets temporary custody of the kid.One thing the guy has going for him is his pseudo girlfriend - I think she was lost on some island or something before making it back to civilization to date losers who fight robots.  Well... regardless of her origins, she likes filthy dudes who gamble and make poor life decisions.Sooo... to make a long story short, the kid finds an old sparing robot named "Atom" (get it, Adam?) buried in a junk heap, fixes it up, and takes to the robot fighting circuit.  Etc, etc, etc.Hey - is it just me or do some of the fight scenes - especially in the last fight with Zeus, mimic Rocky fights?  I swear I was watching Rocky with robots.  I'm not saying it was just close either... I'm talking nearly identical.  I bet you could do a side-by-side comparison and track some of the same moves.Oh - and did anyone else get the impression that perhaps the sparing robot was actually designed by that crazy Asian engineer who designed Zeus?  Recall that he gets asked if Zeus was his best creation and he avoids the question.  Also recall that the owner of Zeus wants to buy Atom - for no reason really.  Also recall that the Asian engineer is always casting worried looks around when he see Atom.  Why?  The movie never actually explains this.  Seems to me like there was a sub-plot that got left out.In terms of special effects, the robots look pretty good.  Frankly, the Transformer movies should have done something a little more like Real Steel.  The fighting robots look "feasible" whereas the Transformers look like a bunch of CGI nonsense.The end result is a movie in which basically everything is predictable - including the end if you have seen Rocky.  However, I don't think that detracted from the film.  My son really liked it and he is in the demographic this film is shooting for.You, of course, know that my taste is impeccable and you live your life based on my reviews.  If you don't, then you better start!  Therefore, you can feel safe watching this film.  4 stars.  Never throw around 5 stars lightly.  I'd probably give it 3 stars based on just my unquestionable taste, but I'm bumping it to 4 because of my son's fondness for the film

reviewText: Real Steel was the kind of sleeper hit that's a bit refreshing in this day and age of massive blockbuster extravaganzas. Granted that the film as a whole is a semi-cliche' mellowdrama with rock 'em sock 'em robots, but hey, there's just something about it that just makes you want to see it. Given that, it doesn't necessarily make Real Steel anything special, and contrary to a majority of viewer's reactions to it, is actually pretty overrated. Hugh Jackman stars as a down and out robot boxing manager that's stuck reconnecting with his estranged 11 year old son, all the while trying to climb back up the ranks of the robot boxing world. That's pretty much it in a nut shell, with Lost vet Evangeline Lilly, Anthony Mackie, and Kevin Durand along for the ride too. The effects are good and the film's action sequences are wonderful, but the overly predictable story and abundance of wanna-be-hipness really hurt the film. All in all, Real Steel isn't bad, but it's nowhere near as special as many have found it to be.

reviewText: "Real Steel" (2011) is a considerably above average example of what I call the "CGI laser light show" movie genre, much better than most (insert "Sucker Punch" here). Think "The Champ" (1931) with elements from "Transformers" (2004), "Rocky" (the 1976 original), and "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" (1991).At its core it is another redemption tale as aging boxer Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman) gets a chance to be a father to the now eleven year-old son he abandoned at birth (Max Kenton - nicely played by Dakota Goyo).  Charlie is informed that his ex-wife has died and he leaps at the chance to cut a deal with his wealthy sister-in-law to give her custody of the boy.  But through a series of somewhat contrived events the jaded Charlie ends up with Max for the first summer.The secret to this type of fairy tale lies in how well they connect with viewers; if the movie can get viewers to strongly identify with the character (in this case Max) as he gets a huge rush from suddenly becoming part of the robot-fighting world, the viewer will get hooked. Then the challenge is to keep them hooked for as long as possible. "Real Steel" hooks you and provides this vicarious rush well past the midway point, in large part because of the twist of having Max bond with the robot as a surrogate father, much in the spirit of "Terminator 2" but also nicely integrated with the ongoing dynamic of the old robot being Charlie's twin or at least the piece than completes him . But eventually the wheels fall off, or in this case get knocked off by a "Rocky" scripted overreach.  The illusion bursts and most viewers crash back to reality because it takes too much mental energy to suspend disbelief when the team breaks into the glitzy celebrity world. From that point on it is just overwrought melodrama, with the inspirational "redemption on steroids" theme aggressively shoved down each viewer's throat.Of course this surfeit of cliché might have been palatable but for Kevin Durand's overplayed heavy.  Like a series of cardiac arrests the heart of the movie first begins beating irregularly during his debt collection sequence, is then severely damaged by his lame homeboys routine, and finally succumbs from his sequence at the conclusion of the first round of the climatic fight.  These would make great deleted scenes for the DVD release but should have been mercifully trimmed from the already too-long film.The one positive of the glitzy sequences was Olga Fonda's "Farra Lemkova" character, an amped up to super-hotness play on WWE's Stephanie McMahon.  She provided the film's most interesting images, a kind of an embodiment of slick temptation.  Can't say the same for Karl Yune's Asian robot designer who essentially was tasked with the Apollo Creed role.  Part of Rocky's success lay in Creed's newly acknowledged respect for Rocky at the conclusion of the film, this allowed the ending to transcend its cliché elements because it nicely blunted the obvious good vs evil dynamic.  Yune was not allowed to play his character this way and "Real Steel" loses considerable depth, dimension, and IQ points because of it.Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.

reviewText: Real Steel will likely be described by many as "Rocky with robots" and that isn't too far off from the central themes that drive the emotions and plot developments. What the film does really well though is balance a family dynamic with the robot boxing action - blending the typical inspirational sports story with a futuristic scenario and relatable characters. It's brilliantly handled and leads to some of the most crowd-pleasing moments I've ever experienced in theater - creating the disctinctly rare desire to see it multiple times.The story takes place in 2020 and centers on Charlie (Hugh Jackman), a down-on-his-luck former boxer turned robot fighter who has to take care of his 11 year old son Max for the summer. The two come across an underdog in a "sparring bot" named Atom who they fix up, train, and fight as they climb the ranks into the established WRB (World Robot Boxing) league.Though it started a little slow, in establishing the circumstances for Charlie, once Atom is discovered it picks up steam and delivers every step of the way. One of few things taken issue with is how he is handed over his son for the summer even though he never showed any capacity to take care of him despite having custody rights. Overlooking that though it made for the effective element of the two getting to know each other through their shared experiences and how Atom inspired something in them both as well as others. Bailey (Evangeline Lilly) anchors Charlie as a reminder of where he came from and that leads to additional pay-off at the end.Pleasantly surprising is how restrained the futuristic elements are presented - everything was plausible and as though it could have realistically evolved out of today's technology. The robots were certainly advanced but it was interesting to see how they had changed from generation to generation. The top dog in WBR is suitably intimidating as are some of the other foes met along the way. They basically have their own personalities.The fights are exceptionally well choreographed and entertaining and that is probably due in large part to bringing in Sugar Ray Leonard to be a consultant on the boxing scenes. These are of course robots but given that they're controlled by humans and in some circumstances regulated by league rules the fights don't just make for a free-for-all but instead tell a story. That is especially important for how Charlie integrates some of his personality into Atom through the training and in-ring strategy.I was completely invested in what was happening on screen. I can't recall ever reacting in the manner that I did at this film for another - applauding and fist pumping at certain moments and cringing from the abuse dealt out during fight scenes. It was also quite funny throughout and it had an excellent score.Full of genuine moments between characters, fantastic robot fighting sequences, and a good number of laughs - Real Steel will have appeal for all audiences. Far more than just a robot boxing film it generates some real emotion and is completely satisfying in its crowd-pleasing nature. Rarely do I make blanket recommendations but I will do so here. Real Steel is a must-see film. You'll be missing out on a great experience otherwise.
summary: Great film that has widespread appeal!

reviewText: ...in good ways and a few bad. First of all let me say, and my rating should suggest, that I recommend this film. I enjoyed it as a fun popcorn movie. Will I buy it? Probably not; but I would watch it again for sure. This film is pure escapsim but in a much more endearing way than most cgi robot films. This is Rocky meets Rock 'em Sock 'em Robots, an odd combination but one that works overall.Hugh Jackman and Evangeline Lilly really make this story work on a much higher level than it should. There is some unrealistic and forced dialogue that is delivered well enough and sincerely enough to keep it from being distracting. The child actor does a decent job and though he isn't always quite natural I can't fault him and he has the personality needed for the role (perhaps his look just reminds me too much of the awful kid who played Anakin Skywalker in Phantom Menace, but this child is far more spirited and likable). The rest of the casting is fun, if not a little stiff, but the film moves along at a pace where you just enjoy the ride and characters serve their purpose.The real stars of the film are Hugh, Evangeline and the young kid (Dakota Goyo) and they keep you involved. Then there is the Real selling point who might also be considered a star, the robot, Atom. He is well designed and even a likable character despite not having a single line of dialogue. I kept expecting them to go in the direction of the robot having an artificial intelligence but thankfully things are left more light and ambiguous.Other positives, the CG is great overall, the cinematograhpy is well done and doesn't make you sick or lose track of the fights. The fight arenas are each different and each of the fights, which can feel repititive in a film like this, feels fresh and distinct in enough ways to stand as unique.The story has some points that don't play as naturally as they could, expository lines and forced scenes, but ultimately all is forgiven in the final showdown when the final blows are thrown as they are (both literally and metaphorically). If the climax of the film doesn't make you cheer it at least makes you feel good and returns you for a brief moment to a level of nostalgic childhood excitement.We all know where the film is going, but it is fun getting there. And we've never seen it done with robots before, so why not? Go out see this film and have some fun, its a good film for the preteen/young adolescent crowd or for families (despite some colorful dialogue from both father and son). reviewText: No? Me neither.I ask the question, because more often than not, blockbusters, or cheesy b movie or fun concepts seem to be falling under that trap nowadays that I assume was set by the otherwise stellar film Inception, where they tried to be too deep and took themselves seriously.Alright, I'll admit, I'm somewhat lying by answering "no" to the question. We did have the 90s, where film's weren't overly pretentious, where they knew what they weren't anything deep, and just went with it and was fun as a result. The Mummy was one I can name. And now, the first movie in a while to just focus kn being entertaining has come out: Real Steel.I was lucky to catch the film at an advance screening tonight, and even despite being a free screening, I felt like I put my money to good use.The film takes place in 2027 and centers around Charlie Kenton, a burnt out boxer who owes over thousands of dollars in unpaid lost robot fights- robot fights having replaced human boxing. After a fiasco that is the result of losing A match against a bull, he discovers an ex girlfriend who had his son has died, and his rather bratty son is being taken not custody by adoptive parents. The parents are given $100 ,000 for custody and Charlie looks after his bratty son, Max, while the adoptive parents are in Italy.After he loses yet ANOTHER fight, which is surprising considering this robot, Noisyboy, is a world renowned robot, he and Max take to the wrecked robot yard to find pieces to create a new robot, when a fall down a cliff results in finding Atom, a G20 sparring bot. They take the bot home and, despite being a sparring bot, Max believes Atom has true potential. After winning a match at a zoo, they realize Atom's true potential, and climb their way up the ladder, in a series of fights leading to the ultimate fight- a fight against a champion robot named Zeus.Real Steel is pure, unadulterated fun. Not once did I feel bored, or beaten over the head with pretentious "symbolism". I went in with no expectations but just a fun rock em sock em robot movie, and came out feeling good about myself and impressed.The reason I enjoyed this so much is for the fact that It knew it wasn't anything deep. I mean, when you have a movie about fighting robots, you want just that, and it gives you that. This wasn't like Transformers 2 or 3 (though 3 was enjoyable) where they took themselves too seriously, and focused more on humans running around trying to figure out supposed conspiracies than the robot fighting. Sure this has some family drama, which is essential to the plot, so no worries there... But even there, the film doesn't take itself too seriously.The film is a tad predictable, which does kind of detract (but only slightly), as you know how the fights are going to end. That said, the predictability does not prevent the fights from being fun and suspenseful. On the topic of the fights themselves, they are ridiculously well done and shot. Apparently they were done with real boxers wearing motion capture suits, and it shows, the fighting is realistic, fluid and human like. The Twin City fight was probably my favourite in the movie! And the final fight is intense, sure to have many on the edge oft heir seats.In short, Real Steel is proof that movies are able to be enjoyable despite being not overly deep, and furthermore are more enjoyable for not trying to be too deep. It's fun, it's funny, it's heartfelt, and is sure to be a real hit this year, as well as I can see a well deserved cult following in this film's future! Don't miss out on it.OVERALL: 9/10PROS: Real Steel is safe, clean fun with lots of exciting robot action, laughs, thrills and heart and doesn't take itself too seriously or try to be too deep. Oh, and you will wish robot boxing existed, so you can buy tickets every weekend!CONS: Predictability, you can tell how it will end from pretty early on.
summary: Remember when movies were enjoyable for the fact that they weren't particularly too deep?

reviewText: Man, Oh Man... is this movie ever a Robo-Smashing good time! But I'm almost certain that Humans will still have boxing matches also.Anyway, Hugh Jackman stars as Charlie, a former boxer who now owns and operates an old beat-up robot boxer named Ambush, which he uses at county fairs and other small shows in battles with other robots to earn a living. He's pretty much a self-centered jerk who suddenly finds himself having to take care of his 11-year-old son, Max, who he abandoned years ago. The two go on robo-battle matches together, where the impatient knee-jerk reactive Charlie embarrasingly loses his latest robo-fighter, Noisy Boy, in a match against another robot named Midas. Noisy Boy gets pretty much trashed in it's losing battle with Midas, leaving Charlie robotless and in desperate need of money, and of course another robot. Later that evening on their way back home from the fight, Charlie and Max obtain an old, abandoned Robo-Boxing training robot named Atom, which they steal from a junkyard in the middle of a rainy night.Max and Charlie clean and polish Atom up, upgrade him, and train him with lots of fancy new moves, then enter him into underground boxing matches where Atom wins fight after fight, and eventually makes his way into an WRBC (World Robot Boxing Championship) match that is televised live on ESPN. Amazingly Atom wins the fight in an upset that has the crowd roaring with applause. After the match, Max makes an announcement live on TV where he challenges the top contending robot champ of all champs, The mighty Zeus, who is the latest in advanced robot boxing technology. Can Atom defeat the mighty Zeus and gain worldwide recognition as a worthy contender, and more importantly, does Charlie finally realize what a schmuck he's been, and become a better Father to his Son, Max?Well, you will just have to watch the movie to find out.Real Steel is a great heartwarming family movie that is loaded with lots of fun, action, and robot fighting scenes that will please the entire family and have them cheering by the movie's end.
